{{mergeto|List of territorial entities where Spanish is an official language|date=February 2018}} The following is a list of countries where [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is an official language, plus a number of countries where Spanish, or any language closely related to it, is an important or significant language. ==Official or national language== Spanish is the majority language in 20 sovereign states and several dependent territories, totaling around 442 million people.{{cite web |url=http://eldiae.es/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/El-espa%C3%B1ol-lengua-viva-2014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903092938/http://eldiae.es/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/El-espa%C3%B1ol-lengua-viva-2014.pdf |archivedate=3 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }} It is additionally the main official language in Equatorial Guinea. In these countries and territories, Spanish is the main or mostly used language of communication of the vast majority of the population; official documents are written chiefly or solely in that language; and it is taught in schools and utilized as the primary medium of instruction as part of the official curriculum. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;" |+ ! |} '''a''' In Spain, Spanish is the sole official language at the national level, while [[Basque language|Basque]], [[Catalan language|Catalan]]/[[Valencian]], [[Aranese language|Aranese]], and [[Galician language|Galician]] are co-official alongside Spanish in certain regions. '''b''' In Peru, Spanish is the sole official language at the national level while [[Quechua language|Quechua]] and [[Aymara language|Aymara]] hold co-official status in selected regions. '''c''' In Ecuador, Spanish is the sole official language at the national level while the [[Kichwa language|Kichwa (Northern Quechua)]] and [[Shuar language|Shuar]] languages hold co-official status in selected regions. '''d''' In Bolivia, the national constitution recognizes Spanish and various [[Languages of Bolivia|indigenous languages of Bolivia]] as official at the national level, though Spanish is predominant nationwide. '''e''' In Paraguay, Spanish and the indigenous [[Guaraní language|Guaraní]] are recognized as co-official at the national level and both are widely used in society. '''f''' Puerto Rico is an unincorporated territory of the U.S. where Spanish and [[English language|English]] are the official languages and Spanish is the primary language. '''g''' In Equatorial Guinea, the Spanish, [[French language|French]], and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] languages all hold official status at the national level, though Spanish is the primary language in the public sphere while [[Fang language|Fang]], [[Bube language|Bube]], [[Kombe language|Kombe]], and other [[Bantu languages]], as well as an English-based creole, are used at home and family settings. See [[Equatorial Guinea#Languages]]. [[File:Spanish speaking countries 2011.jpg|thumb|400px|Population of the Spanish speaking countries (+ [[Puerto Rico]]) in 2011]] ==Significant minority language== Though not an official language at the national level, Spanish is regularly spoken by significant minority populations in each of the nations and territories noted below. In each, public services and information are widely available in Spanish, as are various forms of printed and broadcast media. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;" |+ ! Country ! Population
(2014) ! Total speakers ! Percentage Spanish-speaking |- | style="text-align:left;" | {{flag|Andorra}} || 85,458 || 29,907 || 35% |- | style="text-align:left;" | {{flag|Belize}} || 340,844 || 106,795 || 30% |- | style="text-align:left;" | {{flag|Gibraltar}} || 29,185 || 23,857 || 81% |- | style="text-align:left;" | {{flag|United States of America}} || 318,892,103 || 52,000,000 || 13% |} === Andorra === {{Also|Languages of Andorra}} The Spanish language is not official but also holds a special status (in the education system, the media, and some official documents) in the [[Principality of Andorra]] which shares land borders with Spain.{{cite web |url=http://www.iea.ad/cres/observatori/temes/llengua3trimestre2005.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070717032526/http://www.iea.ad/cres/observatori/temes/llengua3trimestre2005.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 July 2007 |title=Observatori de l'Institut d'Estudis Andorrans|language=Catalan |accessdate=5 June 2013}} === Belize === {{Also|Languages of Belize}} Spanish has no official recognition in the [[Central America]]n nation of [[Belize]], a [[Commonwealth realm]] where English is the official national language. However, the country shares land borders with Spanish-speaking Mexico and Guatemala and, per the 2010 Belizean census, Spanish is spoken by a sizable portion of the population; 30% claim Spanish as a mother tongue and about 50% of the population has working knowledge of the language.Statistical Institute of Belize: Belize Population and Housing Census 2010. Country Report. Belmopan 2013. === Gibraltar === {{Also|Languages of Gibraltar}} The Spanish language is not official but also holds a special status (in the education system, the media, and some official documents) in the [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Gibraltar]], which share land borders with Spain.<[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/constitution/new_constitution/NewGibraltarConstitution.pdf Constitution of Gibraltar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121050613/http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/constitution/new_constitution/NewGibraltarConstitution.pdf |date=21 November 2008 }} === United States === {{Main|Spanish language in the United States}} Spanish has been spoken in the United States for several centuries in the [[Southwestern United States|Southwest]] and [[Florida]], which were all once part of [[New Spain]]. However, today only a tiny minority of Spanish speakers in the US trace their language back to those times; the overwhelming majority of speakers come from recent immigration. Only in northern [[New Mexico]] and southern [[Colorado]] has Spanish maintained speaking communities uninterruptedly since colonial times. {{cite book |last= Canfield|first=Delos Lincoln|date=1981|title=Spanish Pronunciation in the Americas|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|page=80|quote=The main nuclei of Spanish speech in the United States are northern New Mexico / southern Colorado, the border territories from California through Texas, the Florida peninsula, New York City, and other large cities of the Northeast and Midwest. Only one of these, the New Mexico / Colorado dialect area, has maintained linguistic continuity since colonial days, and its speech goes back to about 1600.}} Spanish is the most studied foreign language in United States schools and is spoken as a native tongue by 41 million people, plus an additional 11 million fluent second-language speakers.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jun/29/us-second-biggest-spanish-speaking-country|title=US now has more Spanish speakers than Spain|accessdate=2016-05-09|publisher=theguardian.com}} Though not official, Spanish has a special status for education in the U.S. state of [[New Mexico]]. [http://www.ped.state.nm.us/BilingualMulticultural/dl09/Language%20Rights%20and%20New%20Mexico%20Statehood.pdf ''Language Rights and New Mexico Statehood'' By the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights] With over 50 million native speakers and second language speakers, the United States now has the second largest Spanish-speaking population in the world after Mexico.{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/cultura/speak/spanish/Espana/elpepucul/20081006elpepicul_1/Tes|title=Más 'speak spanish' que en España|accessdate=2007-10-06}} (Spanish) Spanish is increasingly used alongside English nationwide in business and politics. In the United States, the language is regulated by the [[North American Academy of the Spanish Language]]. == Historical language == === Philippines === {{Main|Spanish language in the Philippines}} {{Also|Philippine Spanish}} Spanish was an official language of the [[Philippines]] from the beginning of the [[History of the Philippines (1521–1898)|Hispanic period]] in 1565 and through independence until a constitutional change in 1973. However, [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Ferdinand Marcos]] had Spanish redesigned as an official language under Presidential Decree No. 156, dated 15 March 1973 and Spanish remained official until 1987, when it was re-designated as a voluntary and optional auxiliary language.'''Article XIV, Sec 7''': For purposes of communication and instruction, the official languages of the Philippines are Filipino and, until otherwise provided by law, English. The regional languages are the auxiliary official languages in the regions and shall serve as auxiliary media of instruction therein. '''Spanish''' and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis. On 8 August 2007, [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] announced that the Philippine government asked help from the Spanish Government in her plan to reintroduce Spanish as a required subject in the Philippine school system.{{cite web |url=http://latino.msn.com/noticias/articles/ArticlePage.aspx?cp-documentid=5259791 |title=La presidenta filipina pedirá ayuda a España para oficializar el español |publisher=MSN Noticias |language=Spanish |accessdate=2007-08-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026143031/http://latino.msn.com/noticias/articles/ArticlePage.aspx?cp-documentid=5259791 |archivedate=26 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} By 2012, the language was a compulsory subject at only a very select number of secondary schools.{{cite web |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/264032/news/nation/pnoy-and-spains-queen-sofia-welcome-return-of-spanish-language-in-phl-schools |title=PNoy (President Benigno Aquino III) and Spain’s Queen Sofia welcome return of Spanish language in Philippine schools |first=Amita O. |last=Legaspi |date=3 July 2012 |publisher=GMA News}} In spite of government promotion of Spanish, less than 0.5% of the population are able to speak Spanish at least proficiently.{{Citation|url=https://www.census.gov.ph/data/sectordata/popproj_tab1r.html |publisher=Philippine Statistics Authority |title=Medium projection |date=2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811190921/http://www.census.gov.ph/data/sectordata/popproj_tab1r.html |archivedate=11 August 2011 |df= }} While Spanish is designated as an optional government language in the [[Philippines]], its usage is very limited and not present in everyday life.[http://www.gov.ph/constitutions/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines-article-xiv/ Constitution of the Philippines], Art. 14 In the country, Spanish is regulated by the [[Philippine Academy of the Spanish Language]]. === Western Sahara === Spanish is a secondary official language, alongside [[Arabic language|Arabic]], in the [[Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic]], a former Spanish colony and now a partially recognized state, most of whose territory is occupied by [[Morocco]]. Spanish is not a native language in that country.{{cite web|url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/santiago/2008/03/04/0003_6622703.htm |title=Como saharauis queremos conservar el español |publisher=Lavozdegalicia.es |date=2008-03-13 |accessdate=2015-01-28}}{{cite web|url=http://cvc.cervantes.es/lengua/anuario/anuario_06-07/pdf/paises_3.pdf |format=PDF |title=EL ESPAñOL EN LOS CAMPAMENTOS DE REFUGIADOS SAHARAUIS (TINDUF, ARGELIA) |publisher=Cvc.cervantes.es |accessdate=2015-05-20}} == Creole languages == {{Main|Spanish-based creole languages}} There are a number of Spanish-based [[creole languages]]. [[Chavacano]] is spoken in [[Zamboanga City]] in the Philippines and is a regional language.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/317280/news/nation/deped-adds-7-languages-to-mother-tongue-based-education-for-kinder-to-grade-3 DepEd adds 7 languages to mother tongue-based education for Kinder to Grade 3]. [[GMA News]]. July 13, 2013. [[Papiamento]] is the official language in [[Aruba]], [[Bonaire]] and [[Curaçao]]; it has been classified as either a Spanish-based or a Portuguese-based creole.{{cite web |url=http://www.narin.com/papiamentu/origins.html |title=Papiamentu Facts |accessdate=2008-06-13 |author=Attila Narin |date=June 1998}}{{cite book |last=Dalby |first=Andrew |authorlink=Andrew Dalby |title=Dictionary of Languages |year=1998 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing plc |isbn=0-7475-3117-X |pages=489}} [[Chamorro language|Chamorro]] is an [[Austronesian languages|Austronesian language]] with many Spanish loanwords; some scholars have considered it a creole, but the most authoritative sources deny this. {{cite book|last=Topping|first=Donald|title=Chamorro Reference Grammar|year=1973|publisher=University Press of Hawaii|isbn=978-0-8248-0269-1|pages=6 and 7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iUQle0R4Y3sC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;" ! MA in History of Philosophy | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Narmin Kamal''' ({{lang-az|Nərmin Kamal}}) is a novelist and essayist, author of several books published in Azerbaijan. Azerbaijani literature, although not as well known as its Turkish and Russian cousins, is one of the gems of European culture. ==Life and education== Alongside Azerbaijan, her fiction and non-fiction appeared in various literary anthologies and publications including the New York Times, Der Spiegel, Qantara.de and BBC World Service. As a novelist made her debut with "Aç, mənəm"(2010, Baku, Qanun Publishing), critically acclaimed, won Imadəddin Nəsimi Prize and Young Novelist RFE/Radio Liberty Prize for debut novels in Baku. N.Kamal holds BA(hons) in Philosophy and MA in History of Philosophy from Baku State University. Her PhD dissertation on [https://az.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umberto_Eco_v%C9%99_Postmodernizm_F%C9%99ls%C9%99f%C9%99si Umberto Eco and Postmodern Philosophy] was published in 2008 and 2012 in Baku (Qanun Publishing). She was a guest researcher at [[University of Navarra]] of Spain and [[Bologna University]] of Italy. She was one of twelve European writers invited to write an essay for the young.euro.connect German festival.{{cite web | title=Young Euro Connect | url=http://www.young-euro-connect.de/index.php?seite=s2_4&sprache=eng | work= | publisher=Young Euro Connect | date= | accessdate=2009-05-03}} She was among the six invited to the readings in [[Berlin]] and [[Munich]] in 2008.https://www.tagesspiegel.de/kultur/literatur/literatur-brueder-zur-sauna/1302354.html She was a writer-in-residence at [http://www.kulturkontakt.or.at/html/d/air.asp?guid=%7B025DC425-D5DB-43C9-90CA-BC3C5D02F608%7D Kulturkontakt], Austria/Vienna in 2011. [[File:Writers in residence, Vienna, Austria.jpg|thumb|writer in residence, milo dor]] She gave many speeches and participated in many book festivals, including London, Edinburgh, Wien and Linz book exhibitions. N.Kamal translated [http://Sophie%27s_World Sophie's World] a novel on history of philosophy by Norwegian author Jostein Gaarder from English into Azerbaijani (2010). Her latest book, essay collection of 70 essays was published in Baku, by Alatoran Publishing in 2017, "Küçədən Keçən Adam haqda yazılar" (available in Azerbaijani). 2017, March - "Glückliche Wirkungen: Eine literarische Reise in bessere Welten" (German Edition) [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Glückliche-Wirkungen-literarische-bessere-Welten-ebook/dp/B01N97VTWN] by Ullstein Buchverlage, the anthology includes one essay by N.Kamal. She was one of the founder members of AYO (Azad Yazarlar Ocagi), it was a kind of Bloomsbury Group of Azerbaijan, and deputy editor at [http://alatoran.org/ Alatoran magazine](2004-2008), it was the first independent literature magazine after the authoritarian Soviet legacy of soc-realism, which soon became the voice of a generation. Alatoran published new generation Azerbaijani writers, as well as translations from American and European literature. The group is known today mostly for its dissident voice critisizing the state policy and certain tendencies of the society. == Awards and recognition == 2010 - [http://apa.az/medeniyyet-xeberleri/edebiyyat/nesimi-milli-edebiyyat-mukafati-tesis-edilib.html Imadəddin Nəsimi Fiction Prize] 2011 - "Young Novelist", Radio Liberty Azerbaijani Service's Debut Novel Prize 2010 - The first place among 67 essays at the essay competition titled "The Life and Thoughts of an Azerbaijani Woman", organized in Baku with the generous support of the Women Forum and British Embassy in Baku. 2011 - Milo Dor Stipendium, Austria/Vienna 2015 - [[Rafiq Tağı|Rafig Tagi Award]] 2016 - [http://sozvuchie.by/news/2016-10-03-4 Shortlisted at "Rodnoy Dom" Belarus Short Story Competition] == Books == * Yaquar yerişli zaman. Almanax. 2003, Adiloğlu nəşriyyatı * [https://az.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umberto_Eco_v%C9%99_Postmodernizm_F%C9%99ls%C9%99f%C9%99si "Umberto Eco və Postmodernizm fəlsəfəsi", nəzəri kitab, 2008, 2012, Qanun nəşriyyatı] * [https://www.amazon.de/Freiheit-verstehe-nicht-entbehren-musste/dp/389574705X "Freiheit. Ich verstehe das Wort nicht, weil ich sie nie entbehren musste", Munich, 2009] * [http://www.qanun.az/product/n%C9%99rmin-kamal%E2%80%A9-ac-m%C9%99n%C9%99m/ "Aç, mənəm", roman, 2010, Qanun nəşriyyatı] * [https://kultura.az/news/201408190135341179 Küçədən keçən adam haqda yazılar, Bakı, Alatoran Yayınları, 2017.] * [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Gl%C3%BCckliche-Wirkungen-literarische-bessere-Welten-ebook/dp/B01N97VTWN Glückliche Wirkungen: Eine literarische Reise in bessere Welten (German Edition), 2017] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://en.qantara.de/content/azerbaijans-enlightenment-a-nation-at-odds-with-itself "Azerbaijani Enlightenment", by Nermin Kamal, Deutsche Welle] *[http://aztc.gov.az/en/posts/id:126 Modern Azerbaijani Anthology of Poetry Published in London] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/31/travel/31baku-nextstop.html?_r=0 Old World but Oil Rich in Azerbaijan, The New York Times] *[http://www.qanun.az/?mod=products&id=204 Umberto Eco and Philosophy of Postmodernism. {{sister |project=wiktionary |text=See the [[Wiktionary:Appendix:Fictional English curse words|Fictional English curse words]] appendix in [[Wiktionary]], the free dictionary }} '''Profanity in science fiction''' (SF) shares all of the issues of [[profanity]] in fiction in general, but has several unique aspects of its own, including the use of alien profanities (such as the alien expletive "shazbot!" from ''[[Mork & Mindy]]'', a word that briefly enjoyed popular usage outside of that television show<ref name=EFFL />).
==Extent of usage== In his advice to other SF writers, [[Orson Scott Card]] states that there are no hard-and-fast rules for the use of profanity in SF stories, despite what may have been expected of writers in the past. The onus is squarely on the writer to determine how much profanity to use, to enquire as to each publisher's limits, and to think about the effect that the use of profanity will have on the reader, both in perceiving the characters and in possibly being offended by the story as a whole.<ref name=OSC1 /><ref name=Rogow1991 />
Card urges those writers who do decide to omit profanity from their stories to omit it completely. He regards the coinage of ''tanj'' ("There Ain't No Justice") by [[Larry Niven]] as a "noble experiment" that "proved that euphemisms are often worse than the crudities that they replace", because they make the story look silly. In Card's opinion, such [[nonce word]]s simply don't work.<ref name=OSC1 /><ref name=Rogow1991 />
Ruth Wajnryb shares this opinion, stating that ''tanj'' or ''flarn'' don't work as profanities because they are not real, and are "just a futile attempt to give clean-cut stories some foul-mouthed action".<ref name=Wajnryb2005 />
Jes Battis observes, in contrast, that the use of ''frell'' and ''dren'' in ''[[Farscape]]'' allowed the television series to get away with dialogue that would normally never have made it past broadcasting and network censorship. The words are respectively equivalent to ''[[wikt:fuck|fuck]]'' and ''[[wikt:shit|shit]]'' and are used as both [[interjection]]s and [[noun]]s in the series. In the episode "[[Suns and Lovers]]", for example, [[Aeryn Sun]] says "frell me dead!" as an exclamation of surprise, much as a real-world person would utter "well, fuck me!"{{ref|1|[frell]}} or, indeed, "fuck me dead!" Battis also notes that ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'' used a similar strategy, by using [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin Chinese]] and [[Cantonese]] for all profanities, also using the word ''gorram'' as a replacement for ''god damn'', a phrase usually considered [[blasphemy|blasphemous]].<ref name=Battis1>{{cite book|title=Investigating Farscape|author=Jes Battis|pages=145|publisher=I.B.Tauris|year=2007|isbn= 978-1-84511-342-1}}</ref> Likewise, dialogue in ''[[Battlestar Galactica]]'' is liberally peppered with the word ''frak'' ('fuck').<ref>{{cite news|title=The F-word in Sci-Fi TV shows|work=forums.whirlpool.net.au|date=|url=http://forums.whirlpool.net.au/forum-replies-archive.cfm/318201.html|accessdate=2010-09-14}}</ref>
Similarly, invented expletives are used throughout the [[Star Wars expanded universe|''Star Wars'' expanded universe]]. For example, the Alderaanian expletive ''stang'' was introduced in the 1978 novel ''[[Splinter of the Mind's Eye]]'' and subsequently used in ''Star Wars'' novels, comic books, and games. Also, ''Star Wars'' authors commonly use the Huttese curse ''fierfek'', first introduced in a short story published in the 1996 anthology ''[[Tales from Jabba's Palace]]'', and the Corelian curse ''[[sith]]spawn'', first introduced in the 1994/1995 comic book series ''[[Dark Empire II]]''.
[[Parke Godwin]] opines that excessive profanity, as a part of naturalistic dialogue, "dulls much modern fiction and too many films" and states it to be a pitfall for novice writers, or for writers who never grow up, to fall into. He states that it is a "lazy copout that no longer frightens horses in the street, merely annoys and ultimately bores an intelligent reader". He advises writers that "less is more", and that if it really is the right thing for a character to be salty, it should be made clear to the reader why, observing as an example that in his science fiction novel ''Limbo Search'' the profanity used by character Janice Tyne is a symptom of her fear and tension, caused by being burned out at age 27 and afraid of the future.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Portable Writer's Conference|editor=Stephen Blake Mettee|chapter=Listen!|author=[[Parke Godwin]]|publisher=Quill Driver Books|year=2006|isbn= 978-1-884956-57-7}}</ref>
Wanda Raiford observes that the use of the nonce word ''[[Frak (expletive)|frak]]'' in both ''[[Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)|Battlestar Galactica]]'' series is "an indispensable part of the naturalistic tone that show strives to achieve", noting that it, and ''toaster'' (a [[racial epithet]] for [[Cylon (reimagining)|Cylon]]s), allow the show to use obscene and racialist dialogue that no real-life educated American adult would consider using the real-life equivalents of in polite company. She compares the racial hatred associated with the use of ''[[wikt:nigger|nigger]]'' (an utterance of which she states to have preceded and accompanied "every lynching of a black person in America") to the racial hatred of the Cylons, by the humans, that the use of such phrases as ''frakking toasters'' indicates in the series. She also observes that several of the characters, including [[Gaius Baltar]], are ''frakking toaster lovers''.<ref>{{cite book|title=New Boundaries in Political Science Fiction|editor1=Donald M. Hassler |editor2=Clyde Wilcox |chapter=Race, Robots, and the Law|author=Wanda Raiford|pages=106|publisher=University of South Carolina Press|year=2008|isbn=978-1-57003-736-8}}</ref>
In the series of [[Star Trek: New Frontier]] novels by [[Peter David]], the principal protagonist, Captain Mackenzie Calhoun, frequently utters the word ''grozit'', a curse from his home world of Xenex. It is understood to be the equivalent to ''shit''.
The 2005 video game ''[[Star Wars: Republic Commando]]'' also used ''fierfek'', the expletive popular in the ''[[Star Wars]]'' franchise. This word is described [[in-universe]] as being an alien loan-word originally meaning 'poison', but has been adopted by the game's [[special forces]] [[protagonists]] as a curse word to make the illusion of playing as [[commandos]] more believable.
==Fictional profanities== Profanity in SF also encompasses the idea of things that ''alien cultures'' might find profane, and the notion that what non-humans and humans find to be profane may differ markedly. Card observes that human profanity encompasses words dealing with sexual intercourse and states that that tells one something about human beings. He proceeds to suggest that what aliens might find to be profane can be a useful tool for suggesting the alienness of a culture. The first example of this that he gives are alien cultures that have no trouble with words about sexual intercourse, but that find words to do with ''eating'' to be profane.<ref name=OSC1 /> ''[[Star Trek: Enterprise]]'' made use of this concept in the episode "[[Vox Sola]]".<ref name="Vox_Sola">[http://www.ex-astris-scientia.org/episodes/ent1a.htm Ex Astris Scientia], Enterprise Episodes, Season 2</ref> The second example Card provides is that of alien cultures where the idea of [[ownership|property ownership]] is considered to be as obscene as [[pederasty]].<ref name=OSC1 /> [[Douglas Adams]]'s ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'' at one point mentions that the word [[Belgium]] is the worst profanity in the galaxy.
==In other contexts== As mentioned above, ''shazbot'' briefly enjoyed popular usage outside of its television show.<ref name=EFFL/> ''Battlestar Galactica''{{'}}s ''frak'', a word that [[Lee Goldberg]] characterizes as "something truly amazing and subversive" and that [[Scott Adams]] calls "pure genius", has also escaped its original context. Originally spelled ''frack'', it along with ''felgercarb'' were coined by writer [[Glen A. Larson]] for the 1978 ''[[Battlestar Galactica (1978 TV series)|Battlestar Galactica]]'', for much the same reasons that ''frell'' and ''dren'' were coined for ''Farscape'': the ability to use profane dialogue, with words that would be immediately understood as synonymous with the real profanities that they stood in for, without falling foul of network censorship and broadcasting restrictions accompanying its original Sunday evening broadcast timeslot.<ref name=Talbott2008/>
The producers re-spelled the word ''frak'' for the 2004 ''Battlestar Galactica'' series, in order to make it, literally, a [[four-letter word]];<ref name=Talbott2008/> the word appears in several [[Black Library]] novels before then, most notably the [[Ciaphas Cain]] series.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} It has escaped, in both forms, from the series to a whole variety of other contexts, from a ''[[Dilbert]]'' cartoon strip where [[Dilbert (character)|Dilbert]] mutters it, through other television shows including ''[[The Office]]'', ''[[Gossip Girl (TV series)|Gossip Girl]]'', ''[[Veronica Mars]]'', ''[[30 Rock]]'', and ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'', and [[Robert Crais]]' [[Elvis Cole]] novel ''Chasing Darkness'', to everyday spoken use.<ref name=Talbott2008/>
The [[BBC Two]] [[science fiction television]] series ''[[Red Dwarf]]'' replaces most of its characters' profanities with invented terms, mainly ''[[smeg (vulgarism)|smeg]]'' (possibly a truncation of ''[[smegma]]'') and its compound ''smeg-head''. Other common insults are ''goit'' and ''gimboid''.
== Footnotes == *{{note|1|frell}} Battis has lot to say on Aeryn Sun's use of "frell" here, in terms of its status as a non-performative utterance, and the locutionary and perlocutionary power of the statement. For more detail, see pages 146 et seq. of Battis 2007.<ref name=Battis1 />
== References == {{Reflist|refs= <ref name=EFFL>{{cite book|pages=132|title=Encyclopedia of Fictional and Fantastic Languages|first1=Tim|last1=Conley|first2=Stephen|last2=Cain|author3-link= Ursula K. Le Guin|first3=Ursula K.|last3 = Le Guin|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=2006|isbn= 978-0-313-33188-6}}</ref> <ref name=OSC1>{{cite book|title=How to Write Science Fiction & Fantasy|author=[[Orson Scott Card]]|pages=102–103|publisher=Writer's Digest Books|year=2001|isbn= 978-1-58297-103-2}}</ref> <ref name=Rogow1991>{{cite encyclopaedia|article=TANJ|encyclopedia=FutureSpeak: a fan's guide to the language of science fiction|author=Roberta Rogow|publisher=Paragon House|date=1991|isbn= 978-1-55778-477-3|pages=342}}</ref> <ref name=Talbott2008>{{cite news|url=http://www.aol.co.nz/news/story/What-the-frak'-Faux-curse-seeping-into-language/930021/index.html|title=What the 'frak'? Faux curse seeping into language|author=Chris Talbott|date=2008-09-02|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=Hearst Communications Inc.}}</ref> <ref name=Wajnryb2005>{{cite book|title=Language Most Foul|author=Ruth Wajnryb|pages=175|publisher=Allen & Unwin|year=2005|isbn= 978-1-74114-776-6}}</ref> }}
== See also == * [[Minced oaths in literature]]

'''Project Eden''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] research and development [[private corporation]], which designs products for seniors with [[arthritis]]. Its primary product is the ‘’’Edex’'', a [[writing implement]] which reduces movements traditionally associated with writing. Project Eden was founded in [[Waterloo, Ontario]] and is currently headquartered in [[Kitchener, Ontario]]. Its products are currently manufactured by
== History ==
Project Eden was founded by a group of entrepreneurs in the [[Regional Municipality of Waterloo|Kitchener-Waterloo]] region of [[Ontario]]. Though founded in [[Waterloo, Ontario]], it later relocated to [[Kitchener, Ontario]]. Although it manufactured the first series of Edex writers in house, it later outsourced this work to a company in the [[Greater Toronto Area]].
== Products ==
Project Eden’s main product, the Edex, is a finger mounted writing aid designed to meet the needs of the arthritic population, most of whom are [[Baby boomer|Baby Boomers]]. This target population often find their writing abilities restricted due to pain and frustration, which can be attenuated by the Edex.
The Edex is made of a pair of padded aluminum loops which fit around the index and middle fingers. Any [[writing instrument]] that is attached to the device can be operated with minimal finger movement, allowing the hand to remain close to its rest position. This reduces the problems faced by arthritic seniors when trying to write.
While other products by Project Eden are available in the market, or in the process of being launched, Project Eden has also invested in the research and development of other products for arthritic seniors.
== See also == * [[Arthritis]]
== External links == * [http://www.projecteden.ca Project Eden]

{{Infobox language | name = Rama | nativename = Rama | states = [[Nicaragua]] | region = [[Rama Cay]] | ethnicity = [[Rama people|Rama]] | speakers = 740 | date = 2009 | ref = e19 | familycolor = American | fam1 = [[Chibchan languages|Chibchan]] | fam2 = [[Votic languages|Votic]] | iso3 = rma |glotto=rama1270 |glottorefname=Rama | notice = IPA }}
'''Rama''' is one of the [[indigenous language]]s of the [[Chibchan languages|Chibchan family]] spoken by the [[Rama (people)|Rama people]] on the island of [[Rama Cay]] and south of lake [[Bluefields]] on the Caribbean coast of [[Nicaragua]]. Other indigenous languages of this region include [[Miskito language|Miskito]] and [[Sumo language|Sumu]] {{Harvcol|Craig|1992}}. Rama is one of the northernmost languages of the Chibchan family {{Harvcol|Craig|1990|p=293}}.
The Rama language is severely [[endangered language|endangered]]. Their language was described as "dying quickly for lack of use" as early as the 1860s {{Harvcol|Pim|Seemann|1869|p=280}}. By 1980, the Rama were noted as having "all but lost their original ethnic language", and had become speakers of a form of [[English-based creole languages|English creole]] instead {{Harvcol|Craig|1990|p=293}}. In 1992, only approximately 36 fluent speakers could be found among an ethnic population of 649 individuals in 1992 {{Harvcol|Craig|1992}}. The number of speakers on [[Rama Cay]] island was only 4 in 1992. There have been several language revitalization efforts. The fieldwork for the first dictionary of Rama was done during this time by Robin Schneider, a graduate student from the [[University of Berlin]] {{Harvcol|Rigby|Schneider|1989}}.It is spoken in Honduras and Nicaragua
== Phonology == There are three basic vowel sounds: ''a, i'' and ''u''. In addition to these, ''e'' and ''o'' have been introduced as distinct vowels in some foreign loanwords. Each vowel may be either short or long. Here the vowels are shown in standard Rama orthography (see for example {{Harvcolnb|Craig|Rigby|Assadi|Tibbitts|1988}}):
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" width="50%" |+ Vowels ! ! colspan="2"|[[vowel length|Short]] ! colspan="2"|[[vowel length|Long]] |- ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[High vowel|High]] | '''i''' | '''u''' | '''ii''' | '''uu''' |- ! [[Mid vowel|(Mid)]] | '''(e)''' | '''(o)''' | '''(ee)''' | '''(oo)''' |- ! [[Low vowel|Low]] |colspan="2"|'''a''' |colspan="2"|'''aa''' |}
The following consonants are found ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] transcriptions are shown where helpful):
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Consonants ! ! [[Bilabial]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! [[labialized velar consonant|Labiovelar]] ! [[glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! [[Voiceless]] [[Plosive]]s | '''p''' | '''t''' | | '''k''' | '''kw''' {{IPA|[kʷ]}} | |- ! [[Voiced]] [[Plosives]] | '''b''' | '''d''' | | '''g''' | | |- ! [[Fricative]]s | | '''s''' | | | | '''h''' |- ! [[Nasal stop|Nasals]] | '''m''' | '''n''' | | '''ng''' {{IPA|[ŋ]}} | '''ngw''' {{IPA|[ŋʷ]}} | |- ! [[Liquids]] | | '''l''', '''r''' | | | | |- ! [[Semivowel]]s | | | '''y''' | | '''w''' | |- |}
Rama words have non-predictable stress.<ref>Lehmann's vocabulary {{Harvcol|Lehmann|1914}} indicates stress; modern standard spelling does not.</ref>
=== Phonotactics and sandhi === Rama [[phonotactics]] includes notable consonant clusters at the beginning of words (e.g. {{lang|rma|psaarik|italic=yes}} "toucan", {{lang|rma|tkua|italic=yes}} "hot", {{lang|rma|nkiikna|italic=yes}} "man", {{lang|rma|mlingu|italic=yes}} "killed") and word-internally (e.g. {{lang|rma|alkwsi|italic=yes}} "speaks", {{lang|rma|salpka|italic=yes}} "fish"). Variations among speakers witness a tendency to simplify such clusters (e.g. {{lang|rma|nkiikna|italic=yes}} or {{lang|rma|kiikna|italic=yes}} "man", {{lang|rma|nsu-|italic=yes}} or {{lang|rma|su-|italic=yes}} "we, us, our").
Such clusters often arise due to a tendency to omit unstressed short vowels. For example, when the third person singular subject prefix ''i-'' and the past tense suffix ''-u'' are added to the verb stem {{lang|rma|kwis|italic=yes}} "eat", thus: ''i-'' + {{lang|rma|kwis|italic=yes}} + ''-u'', the verb stem loses its only vowel, resulting in the form {{lang|rma|ikwsu|italic=yes}} "he/she/it ate". Sometimes omitting different vowels may lead to alternative results. Adding the past tense suffix ''-u'' to the verb stem {{lang|rma|maling|italic=yes}} "kill", i.e. {{lang|rma|maling|italic=yes}} + ''-u'', may give either {{lang|rma|mlingu|italic=yes}} or {{lang|rma|malngu|italic=yes}} "killed".
There are also cases of vowel alternation in morphemes (e.g. the first-person subject prefix may appear as ''n-, ni-'' or ''na-'') and lexical stems (thus the stem {{lang|rma|aakar|italic=yes}} "stay" may appear in the forms ''aak'''i'''r-i'' "stays" and ''aaik'''u'''r-u'' "stayed", where the short stem vowel copies the vowel of the suffix).
Consonants display a degree of [[sandhi]]-type alternation, as seen for example in the final consonant of the same stem {{lang|rma|aakar|italic=yes}} "stay, be", cf. the imperative {{lang|rma|aaki'''t'''|italic=yes}} "stay!". This latter variant is found both word-final and before a suffix beginning with a consonant (e.g. {{lang|rma|aaki'''t'''-ka|italic=true}} "if there is").
== Grammar == In terms of grammatical typology Rama may be considered a fairly "normal" language for the linguistic area within which it is located, despite the lack of close genetic ties with its immediate neighbours. For example, Rama shares some general typological features with [[Miskito language|Miskito]], a dominant contact language, displaying many characteristics typical of SOV languages (even though not all sentences are actually verb-final). A single set of prefixes serves to express both pronominal possessors (e.g. ''n-''{{lang|rma|up|italic=yes}} "my eye") and subjects (e.g. ''n-''{{lang|rma|taaku|italic=yes}} "I went"). Noun phrase relations are indicated by postpositions, tense and [[subordination (linguistics)|subordination]] by verbal suffixes.<ref>Sources for the information in this section include {{Harvcolnb|Craig|1991}}, {{Harvcolnb|Craig|Rigby|Assadi|Tibbitts|1988}}, {{Harvcolnb|Lehmann|1914}} and {{Harvcolnb|Rigby|Craig|Tibbitts|1989}}, and also the Rama texts in {{Harvcolnb|Craig|Tibbits|Rigby|1986}} and {{Harvcolnb|Craig|Tibbits|Rigby|Benjamins|1992}}. There are some notable differences between the earlier and more recent descriptions; cf. {{Harvcolnb|Craig|1991}}: "The discrepancy between the earlier data and that which are presented here begs the question of whether it is due to the way the data were gathered, or whether it is an indication of linguistic change, or both." For practical reasons and coherence, the present sketch focuses on the recent data found in the materials produced by the present language recovery movement.</ref>
=== Noun phrase ===
==== Elements of the noun phrase ==== There are no articles. Nouns are frequently undetermined, e.g. {{lang|rma|Pkaak tkii su itraali|italic=yes}} "(The) lizard walks on (the) ground" (literally: lizard ground on (s)he-walks), {{lang|rma|Salpka sauk u ikuu|italic=true}} "He/she caught (a) fish with (a) hook" (fish hook with (s)he-caught).
Demonstrative determiners precede the noun: {{lang|rma|'''ning''' nguu|italic=yes}} "'''this''' house", {{lang|rma|'''naming''' tausung|italic=yes}} "'''that''' dog". Quantifiers follow the noun: {{lang|rma|tausung '''saiming'''|italic=yes}} "'''one''' dog", {{lang|rma|puus '''puksak'''|italic=yes}} "'''two''' cats",<ref>The earliest studies of the Rama language, for example {{Harvcolnb|Lehmann|1911}}, mistakenly identified it as having [[classifier (linguistics)|classifiers]]; this was later demonstrated to be untrue {{Harvcol|Craig|2000|p=60}}.</ref> {{lang|rma|nguu '''ngarak'''|italic=true}} "'''many''' houses", {{lang|rma|tamaaski '''ui'''|italic=true}} "'''every''' morning", {{lang|rma|kaulingdut '''umling'''|italic=true}} "'''all''' the people", {{lang|rma|tausung '''saina'''|italic=true}} "the '''other''' dog, '''another''' dog".
Most nouns do not change for [[grammatical number|number]], but those denoting humans can take the plural suffix {{lang|rma|-dut|italic=true}} or {{lang|rma|-lut|italic=true}}, as in {{lang|rma|kiikna'''dut'''|italic=true}} "men", {{lang|rma|kumaa'''lut'''|italic=true}} "women", {{lang|rma|tiiskama'''lut'''|italic=true}} "children", etc.
Attributive adjectives follow the noun they qualify: {{lang|rma|salpka '''taara'''|italic=true}} "(a/the) '''big''' fish".
==== Possession ==== Inalienable pronominal possession, found with body parts and characteristics, is expressed by prefixes attached to the possessed noun: {{lang|rma|'''n'''up|italic=true}} "'''my''' eye", {{lang|rma|'''y'''ausa|italic=true}} "'''his/her''' strength", {{lang|rma|'''nsu'''suluk|italic=true}} "'''our''' fingers".<ref>There may have been variation over time as to which nouns are treated as inalienable. For example, in modern sources {{lang|rma|maing aak|italic=true}} "your name" is found, with {{lang|rma|aak|italic=true}} treated as alienable, but {{Harvcolnb|Lehmann|1914}} has {{lang|rma|maak|italic=true}} "your name".</ref>
In other cases (including kinship relations), a genitive pronoun (formed from the pronominal prefix + {{lang|rma|-aing|italic=true}}) precedes the possessed noun, e.g. {{lang|rma|'''naing''' puus / nguu / aak / tiiskama / taata / tairung|italic=true}} "'''my''' cat / house / name / child / father / sister", {{lang|rma|'''maing''' kaulingdut|italic=true}} "your family (lit. your people)", {{lang|rma|'''yaing''' aak|italic=true}} "'''his/her''' name", {{lang|rma|'''nsulaing''' rama kuup|italic=true}} "'''our''' Rama language".
The forms {{lang|rma|naing, maing, yaing|italic=true}} etc. also function predicatively (as equivalents of English possessive pronouns), as in {{lang|rma|Naming puus '''naing'''|italic=true}} "That cat is '''mine'''".
Nominal possession is expressed by two constructions: possessor + possessed (i.e. simple juxtaposition), e.g. {{lang|rma|naing taata aak|italic=true}} "my father's name" (my father name), and possessor + {{lang|rma|aing|italic=true}} + possessed ({{lang|rma|aing|italic=true}} being a genitive postposition), e.g. {{lang|rma|Nora '''aing''' nguu|italic=true}} "Nora's house".
==== Pronouns ==== Personal pronouns have free (independent) and bound (prefix) forms as in the following table. The third person singular bound form is ''i-'' before a consonant or ''y-'' before a vowel.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" width="40%" |+ Personal pronouns ! ! Independent ! Prefix |- ! I, me | {{lang|rma|naas, na|italic=true}} | ''n-'' |- ! you (sg.) | {{lang|rma|maa|italic=true}} | ''m-'' |- ! he/him, she/her, it | {{lang|rma|yaing|italic=true}} | ''i-, y-'' |- ! we, us | {{lang|rma|nsut|italic=true}} | ''nsu-'' |- ! you (pl.) | {{lang|rma|mlut|italic=true}} | ''m- -lut'' |- ! they, them | {{lang|rma|anut|italic=true}} | ''an-'' |}
The independent pronouns are often used as subjects: {{lang|rma|'''Nah''' tawan ki aakar|italic=true}} "'''I''' live in Bluefields" (I town in stay), {{lang|rma|'''Maa''' kalma apaakut?|italic=true}} "Can '''you''' sew a dress?" (you dress sew-IRREALIS), {{lang|rma|'''Yaing''' taaki|italic=true}} "'''He/She''' is going". They may also be complements of postpositions: {{lang|rma|Naing airung ning nguu ki aakar '''nah''' u|italic=true}} "My mother lives in this house with '''me'''" (my mother this house in stay I with), {{lang|rma|'''maa''' kang|italic=true}} "from '''you'''", {{lang|rma|Walsa '''anut''' su tabiu|italic=true}} "The tiger came out at '''them'''" (tiger they at came-out). Note that ''-ut'' changes to ''-ul'' before a vowel, for example in {{lang|rma|nsul u|italic=true}} "with us".
The prefix forms of the pronouns are used as subject prefixes with verbs: {{lang|rma|Neli aa '''ni'''tangu|italic=true}} "I gave it to Nelly" (Nelly OBJECT I-gave), {{lang|rma|Tamaik suulikaas '''ni'''aukut|italic=true}} "Tomorrow I will cook some meat" (tomorrow meat I-will-cook), {{lang|rma|Taa u '''m'''taaku?|italic=true}} "With whom did you go?" (who with you-went), {{lang|rma|'''I'''taaku|italic=true}} "he/she went", {{lang|rma|Ipang su '''an'''siiku|italic=true}} "'''They''' came to the island" (island in they-came). In the second person plural, ''m-'' is prefixed and ''-lut'' suffixed to the verb.
Subject prefixes are omitted when the subject is represented by an independent pronoun: "I am going" is either {{lang|rma|Nah taaki|italic=true}} or {{lang|rma|Ntaaki|italic=true}}, "He is going" is either {{lang|rma|Yaing taaki|italic=true}} or {{lang|rma|Itaaki|italic=true}}, etc. They are also commonly absent in the presence of a full subject noun phrase: {{lang|rma|Naing taata taaki|italic=true}} "My father is going", but "repetition" of the subject is also possible: {{lang|rma|Pkaak tkii su itraali|italic=true}} "The lizard (he) walks on the ground" (lizard ground on it-walks).
A pronominal object is expressed by adding the postposition ''aa'' to the pronouns, which adopt the prefix form in the singular but the full form in the plural: {{lang|rma|naa, maa, yaa|italic=true}} but {{lang|rma|nsula|italic=true}} (for {{lang|rma|nsut + -a|italic=true}}) etc. But third person objects are commonly zero-marked, that is, the absence of an overt object of a transitive verb implies an understood "him", "her" or "it", e.g. ''Anangsku'' "They cleaned it" (lit. they-cleaned).
The demonstrative pronouns are the same as the corresponding determiners: {{lang|rma|ning|italic=true}} "this", {{lang|rma|naming|italic=true}} "that", as in {{lang|rma|Ning naing nguu|italic=true}} "This is my house".
The interrogative pronouns are {{lang|rma|niku|italic=true}} "what", {{lang|rma|taa|italic=true}} "who", as in {{lang|rma|Niku maing aak?|italic=true}} "What is your name?", {{lang|rma|Taa rama kuup alkwsi?|italic=true}} "Who speaks Rama?" (who Rama language speaks), {{lang|rma|Taa u mtaaku?|italic=true}} "With whom did you go?" (who with you-went).
==== Postpositions ==== Rama [[postpositions]] perform roughly the same functions as English prepositions, as in {{lang|rma|tkii '''su'''|italic=true}} "'''on''' the ground", {{lang|rma|tawan '''ki'''|italic=true}} "'''in''' (the) town", {{lang|rma|nah '''u'''|italic=true}} "'''with''' me", {{lang|rma|nguu '''aing'''|italic=true}} "'''of''' the house", etc.
Postpositional phrases may occur either before or after the verb. Some postpositions have a shorter and a longer form; following the verb the long forms are used, e.g. {{lang|rma|Nangalbiu naing taata '''kang'''|italic=true}} "I ran away from my father" (I-ran my father from) but before the verb the short forms are more usual: {{lang|rma|Naing taata '''ka''' nangalbiu|italic=true}} (my father from I-ran).

Meaning or function |- | {{lang|rma|aak|italic=true}} | {{lang|rma|aa|italic=true}} | object marker |- | colspan=2|{{lang|rma|aing|italic=true}} | "of, for", genitive |- | {{lang|rma|bang|italic=true}} | {{lang|rma|ba|italic=true}} | "to, for" |- | colspan=2|{{lang|rma|isii|italic=true}} | "like" |- | colspan=2|{{lang|rma|kama|italic=true}} | "for" |- | {{lang|rma|kang|italic=true}} | {{lang|rma|(i)ka|italic=true}} | "from" |- | colspan=2|{{lang|rma|ki|italic=true}} | "in, on, at, to" |- | {{lang|rma|king|italic=true}} | {{lang|rma|ki|italic=true}} | "for" |- | colspan=2|{{lang|rma|su|italic=true}} | "in, on, at, to" |- | colspan=2|{{lang|rma|u|italic=true}} | "with" |}
Although {{lang|rma|aak|italic=true}} or {{lang|rma|aa|italic=true}} is given as an object marker, most objects (other than personal pronouns) take no postposition, e.g. {{lang|rma|Kruubu '''kiikna''' kwisu|italic=true}} "The tiger ate the man" (tiger man ate).
In addition to the simple postpositions there are more complex forms of the [[relational noun|relational]] type that express more specific relationships. These are composed of a noun-like lexical form followed by a postposition, such as {{lang|rma|psutki|italic=true}} "inside", {{lang|rma|karka|italic=true}} "out of". They are placed after a noun phrase, e.g. {{lang|rma|ngurii psutki|italic=true}} "inside the hole", or a postpositional phrase, e.g. {{lang|rma|ung su karka|italic=true}} "out of the pot" (literally: pot in out-from). Such expressions may also be used adverbially.
=== The verb ===
==== Overview ==== The simplest structure for verb forms consists of these elements:
# an optional '''subject prefix''' (already discussed above under Pronouns) # the verb '''stem''' # either a '''tense/mood''' suffix (or zero) or a '''subordination''' marker
e.g. {{lang|rma|Nah tawan ki '''aakar'''|italic=true}} "I live in Bluefields" (no subject prefix and no tense suffix), {{lang|rma|Yaing '''taak-i'''|italic=true}} "He/She is going" (no subject prefix, present tense suffix), {{lang|rma|Taa u '''m-taak-u'''?|italic=true}} "With whom did you go?" (second person subject prefix, past tense suffix), {{lang|rma|Suulikaas '''ni-auk-ut'''|italic=true}} "I will cook some meat" (first person subject prefix, future/irrealis suffix), {{lang|rma|kruubu '''an-sung-ka'''|italic=true}} "when they see the tiger" (third person plural subject prefix, "when" subordinator), {{lang|rma|Nah suulikaas baalpi '''ni-paya-kama'''|italic=true}} "I am looking for meat to buy" (first person singular subject prefix, purpose subordinator).
This basic structure may be expanded by adding other elements, including aspect markers (which come between the stem and the tense/mood suffix) and preverbs (which precede the subject prefix, if present). More complex meanings can be expressed through the use of serial verb constructions.
==== Tense/mood and subordinator suffixes ==== Most verb forms end in a suffix such as one of the following which either specifies a tense (or a mood) or else signals a subordinate clause:<ref>The table does not aim to be exhaustive but covers the most basic options.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" width="60%" |+ Tense/mood and subordinator suffixes ! colspan="2"|Tense/mood suffixes ! colspan="2"|Subordinator suffixes |- ! Suffix ! Meaning ! Suffix ! Meaning |- | {{lang|rma|-i|italic=true}} | present tense | {{lang|rma|-bang|italic=true}} | "in order to" |- | {{lang|rma|-u|italic=true}} | past tense | {{lang|rma|-ka|italic=true}} | "when, if" |- | {{lang|rma|-ut|italic=true}} | future/irrealis | {{lang|rma|-kama|italic=true}} | "in order to" |- | rowspan=2|no suffix | tenseless/habitual | {{lang|rma|-kata|italic=true}} | "if" |- | imperative | {{lang|rma|-su|italic=true}} | "upon, and then, since" |}
Use of one of the subordinator suffixes constitutes the main subordination strategy. Since these suffixes occupy the same place as the tense suffixes, the resulting subordinate clauses are tenseless, in this respect resembling non-finite clauses in European languages. Nonetheless, Rama verb forms with subordinators take subject prefixes under the same basic conditions as tensed ones, and in this way resemble finite forms.
Examples with {{lang|rma|siik|italic=true}} "come": {{lang|rma|nsiiki|italic=true}} "I am coming", {{lang|rma|nsiiku|italic=true}} "I came", {{lang|rma|nsiikut|italic=true}} "I will come", {{lang|rma|nsiikbang|italic=true}} "for me to come", {{lang|rma|nsiikka|italic=true}} "when I come", {{lang|rma|nsiikkata|italic=true}} "if I come" etc.
In some cases the lack of any suffix signals a lack of marked tense or a habitual sense: compare {{lang|rma|Ntaakkama '''aakari'''|italic=true}} "I am ready to go" (now) with {{lang|rma|Nah tawan ki '''aakar'''}} "I live in the town". Imperatives in the second person singular are also suffixless, e.g. {{lang|rma|Siik!}} "Come!" One verb, {{lang|rma|taak}} "go", has a suppletive imperative {{lang|rma|mang!}} or {{lang|rma|bang!}} "go!".
Sometimes forms with the ''-bang'' suffix are used in independent clauses: see the section on Aspect below.
==== Aspect ==== Using the simple past tense of {{lang|rma|kwis|italic=true}} "eat", the sentence {{lang|rma|Kruubu kiikna kwisu|italic=true}} means "The tiger ate the man", but the "manner of eating" may be specified further to express completion of the action by adding to the stem {{lang|rma|kwis|italic=true}} the aspect marker {{lang|rma|-atkul|italic=true}}, giving {{lang|rma|Kruubu kiikna kwisatkulu|italic=true}} "The tiger ate the man all up". Further examples with {{lang|rma|-atkul-|italic=true}} are: {{lang|rma|Dor yakaangatkulu|italic=true}} "He/she shut the door tight" ({{lang|rma|akaang|italic=true}} "close") and {{lang|rma|Paalpa ansungatkulu|italic=true}} "They saw the whole manatee" ({{lang|rma|sung|italic=true}} "see"). Another aspect-marking suffix similarly used is {{lang|rma|-atkar|italic=true}} ({{lang|rma|-itkr-|italic=true}}) expressing repetition.
A range of further aspectual nuances may be conveyed by a variety of periphrastic constructions. Several of these involve the verb {{lang|rma|aakar|italic=true}} "stay" or its derivative {{lang|rma|baakar|italic=true}} (which contains the preverb {{lang|rma|ba-|italic=true}}), either of which, following a verb stem, may convey progressive aspect: {{lang|rma|Nah paun baakiri|italic=true}} "I am crying" ({{lang|rma|paun|italic=true}} "cry"; the second vowel in {{lang|rma|aakar|italic=true}} can copy the vowel of the suffix). {{lang|rma|Baakar|italic=true}} can also express "be about to (do something)".
The suffix {{lang|rma|-bang|italic=true}} (see also above) may express intention, as in {{lang|rma|Tiiskama nitanangbang|italic=true}} "I am going to look at the baby" ({{lang|rma|tanang|italic=true}} "look at"), and in first person plural imperatives (i.e. "let's..."), as in {{lang|rma|Nsukamibang!|italic=true}} "Let's sleep!" ({{lang|rma|kami|italic=true}} "sleep"). In the latter use the subject prefix may be omitted, e.g. {{lang|rma|Rama kuup alkwisbang!|italic=true}} "Let's speak Rama!" ({{lang|rma|alkwis|italic=true}} "speak").
A form related to {{lang|rma|bang|italic=true}}, {{lang|rma|bating|italic=true}}, means "want" with a nominal object, as in {{lang|rma|Sumuu ibatingi|italic=true}} "He/she wants a banana", but with verbal complements means "be going to (do something)" in the simple form, as in {{lang|rma|Itraat batingi|italic=true}} "He/she is going to walk" ({{lang|rma|traat|italic=true}} "walk"), or "get ready to (do something)" in the progressive {{lang|rma|baakar|italic=true}} construction, as in {{lang|rma|Nalngu bating baakiri|italic=true}} "I get ready to drink" ({{lang|rma|alngu|italic=true}} "drink").
Another periphrasis, constructed with {{lang|rma|aakar|italic=true}} following the subordinate form in {{lang|rma|-kama|italic=true}} of the main verb, expresses "be ready to (do something)", e.g. {{lang|rma|Ntaakkama aakari|italic=true}} "I am ready to go" ({{lang|rma|taak|italic=true}} "go").
One other means of expressing aspectual (or mood) nuances is provided by the use of a second set of emphatic tense suffixes which replace the simple suffixes, namely {{lang|rma|-aing|italic=true}} emphatic affirmative, {{lang|rma|-uing|italic=true}} habitual past and {{lang|rma|-uting|italic=true}} emphatic future.
==== Modality ==== Modal notions are expressed by further periphrastic constructions. A verb with the {{lang|rma|-kama|italic=true}} suffix may be used in an independent clause to convey obligation: {{lang|rma|Tiiskiba umling '''taakkama''' skuul ki|italic=true}} "All the children must go to school". {{lang|rma|Ikar|italic=true}} is used as a modal auxiliary of volition, as in {{lang|rma|Nah rama kuup larn tang ikri|italic=true}} "I want to learn Rama" ({{lang|rma|larn tang|italic=true}} "learn"). Ability may be expressed by the future/irrealis tense form in {{lang|rma|-ut|italic=true}}, e.g. {{lang|rma|Maa kalma apaakut?|italic=true}} "Will/can you sew a dress?" Inability is expressed by the negator {{lang|rma|angka|italic=true}} preceding the complete verb, e.g. {{lang|rma|Nah rama kuup angka alkwsi|italic=true}} "I cannot speak Rama".
==== Preverbs ==== Rama has [[preverb]]s which form constructions comparable to English [[phrasal verb]]s such as "run ''away''", "come ''over''", "carry ''on''" etc. The Rama preverbs resemble some of the postpositions in form: they are {{lang|rma|ba-, yu-, ka-, su-|italic=true}} and {{lang|rma|yaa-|italic=true}}. Like English phrasal verbs, the meanings and uses of Rama preverb constructions can be quite idiomatic and unpredictable. Preverbs precede the subject prefix if present: {{lang|rma|'''Ka'''nangalbiu|italic=true}} "I ran away from (him/her)" ({{lang|rma|ngalbi|italic=true}} "run" with the preverb {{lang|rma|ka-|italic=true}} "from": {{lang|rma|-na-|italic=true}} is the subject prefix). {{lang|rma|Ngulkang tawan ki '''yu'''ansiiku|italic=true}} "They brought the wild pig to the town" ({{lang|rma|yu-siik|italic=true}} "come with, i.e. bring"). {{lang|rma|Tiiskama taa '''yu'''taaku?|italic=true}} "Who took the child?" ({{lang|rma|yu-taak|italic=true}} "go with, i.e. take").
While many preverb-verb combinations are lexically specified, {{lang|rma|yu-|italic=true}} may also be used productively to express an instrumental argument, e.g. {{lang|rma|Nainguku kiskis nsukuaakari, suulikaas '''yu'''nsuaukkama|italic=true}} "That's why we have tongs, in order to roast meat with (them)" (therefore tongs we-have, meat for-we-roast-with).
==== Serial verbs ==== A limited range of serial-type constructions are found. A notable case of this is the use of the verb {{lang|rma|traal|italic=true}} "walk" following another verb, as in: {{lang|rma|Ipang ika kiikna paalpa baanalpi '''traali''' lakun aik|italic=true}} "Men of Rama Cay go to look for manatee in the lagoon" (island from man manatee they-seek walk lagoon side). The morphological analysis of {{lang|rma|baanalpi traali|italic=true}} "they go to look for" is: {{lang|rma|ba-an-alpi traal-i|italic=true}} (PREVERB-they-seek walk-PRESENT).
=== The sentence ===
==== 'Be' and 'have' ==== Noun and adjective predicates are constructed without a copula, in the order Subject + Predicate, e.g. {{lang|rma|Ning naing nguu|italic=true}} "This is my house" (this my house), {{lang|rma|Yaing aak Basilio|italic=true}} "His name is Basilio" (his name Basilio), {{lang|rma|Paalpa suuli taara|italic=true}} "The manatee is a big animal" (manatee animal big), {{lang|rma|Naing nguu aakwaala|italic=true}} "My house is pretty" (my house pretty); so also {{lang|rma|Naming puus naing|italic=true}} "That cat is mine" and {{lang|rma|Naing puus suuk mlingkama|italic=true}} "My cat is for killing rats". The Subject + Predicate order is inverted in a question such as {{lang|rma|Niku yaing aak?|italic=true}} "What is his name?"
The verb {{lang|rma|aakar|italic=true}} "stay" is used to express "be (in a place)" and "be (in a state)", as in {{lang|rma|Skuul saud aap su aakar|italic=true}} "The school is on the south side" (school south side in stay), {{lang|rma|Nah mliika aakar|italic=true}} "I am fine" (I well stay). {{lang|rma|Aakar|italic=true}} can also mean "live (in a place)" as in {{lang|rma|Nah ipang su aakar|italic=true}} "I live on Rama Cay" (I island in stay), and "there is" as in {{lang|rma|Nguu ngarak ipang su aakar|italic=true}} "There are many houses on Rama Cay" (house many island in stay).
The verb {{lang|rma|kuaakar|italic=true}} (or {{lang|rma|kwaakar|italic=true}}) means "have", e.g. {{lang|rma|Nah nising puksak kuaakar|italic=true}} "I have two sisters" (I sister two have), {{lang|rma|Nainguku kiskis nsukuaakari|italic=true}} "That's why we have tongs", {{lang|rma|Puupu kwiik ngarak ikuaakari|italic=true}} "The octopus has many arms".
==== Word order with verbal predicates ==== In sentences with a verb as predicate, the basic order is: * SV if intransitive, e.g. {{lang|rma|Sukmurk tkari|italic=true}} "The frog jumps", {{lang|rma|Nah paun baakiri|italic=true}} "I am crying" (I cry AUXILIARY), {{lang|rma|Naing tiiskama almlingi|italic=true}} "My child is sick" (my child is-sick) * SOV if transitive (assuming that both arguments are present as noun phrases in the utterance), e.g. {{lang|rma|Kruubu kiikna kwisu|italic=true}} "The tiger ate the man" (tiger man ate), {{lang|rma|Nora rama kuup alkwsi|italic=true}} "Nora speaks Rama" (Nora Rama language speaks), ''Nah tausung saiming kuaakar'' "I have one dog" (I dog one have). Other sentence elements (in bold here) may be placed: * in front of the verb: {{lang|rma|Pkaak '''tkii su''' itraali|italic=true}} "The lizard walks '''on the ground'''", {{lang|rma|Tulkumas '''ituk u''' naayarnguli|italic=true}} "The scorpion bites '''with its tail'''", {{lang|rma|'''Ipang su''' ansiiku|italic=true}} "They came '''to the island'''", {{lang|rma|Nguu ngarak '''ipang su''' aakar|italic=true}} "There are many houses '''on the island'''", {{lang|rma|'''Nah u''' alkwis!|italic=true}} "Speak '''with me'''!", {{lang|rma|Nah '''yaabra aap su''' aapunu|italic=true}} "I grew up '''on the south side'''", {{lang|rma|Naas '''sii ba''' taak ikar|italic=true}} "I don't want to go '''for water'''", {{lang|rma|Salpka taara '''sauk u''' ikuu|italic=true}} "He caught a big fish '''with a hook'''", {{lang|rma|Kruubu '''tamaaski ui''' tabii|italic=true}} "The tiger came out '''every morning'''". * at the end of the sentence (i.e. after the verb): {{lang|rma|Nsut rama larn tangi '''Nora u'''|italic=true}} "We are learning Rama '''with Nora'''", {{lang|rma|Naing airung ning nguu ki aakar '''nah u'''|italic=true}} "My mother lives in this house '''with me'''", {{lang|rma|Nkiikna ngulkang malngi '''twiis u'''|italic=true}} "The man kills the wari '''with a lance'''", {{lang|rma|Maa kalma apaakut '''naing isii'''?|italic=true}} "Can you sew a dress '''like mine'''?", {{lang|rma|Naing taata ngabang yuisiiku '''nguu ki'''|italic=true}} "My father brings the silkgrass '''into the house'''", {{lang|rma|kiskis yuisiikka '''nguu ki'''|italic=true}} "when he brings the tongs '''into the house'''", {{lang|rma|yupsi tabii '''ung su karka'''|italic=true}} "when the oil comes '''out of the pot'''". * or at the beginning of the sentence: {{lang|rma|'''Ipang su''' nah maktungu|italic=true}} "I was born '''on Rama Cay'''", {{lang|rma|'''Ngurii psutki''' yaing tiiskama yuitaaki|italic=true}} "She took the child '''inside the hole'''", {{lang|rma|'''Ung ariis ba''' upsi ankai|italic=true}} "They put the oil '''in the empty pot'''", {{lang|rma|'''Tamaik''' suulikaas niaukut|italic=true}} "'''Tomorrow''' I will cook meat". Clausal elements (i.e. those containing a verb) usually follow the main verb, e.g. {{lang|rma|Nah taaki '''ai nipiabang'''|italic=true}} "I am going '''to plant corn'''", {{lang|rma|Nah suulikaas baalpi '''nipayakama'''|italic=true}} "I am looking for meat '''to buy'''", {{lang|rma|Mliika anaakar '''paalpa analkuka'''|italic=true}} "They are happy '''when they hear about the manatee'''".
==== Questions ==== Yes/no questions take the same form as the corresponding statement, e.g. {{lang|rma|Maing nguu taara?|italic=true}} "Is your house big?", {{lang|rma|Maa ipang su aakar?|italic=true}} "Do you live on Rama Cay?", {{lang|rma|Maa rama kuup alkwsi?|italic=true}} "Do you speak Rama?", {{lang|rma|Maa nising kuaakar?|italic=true}} "Have you a sister?", {{lang|rma|Maa kalma apaakut naing isii?|italic=true}} "Can you sew a dress like mine?" Such questions may be answered using {{lang|rma|Aha|italic=true}} "Yes" or {{lang|rma|Mahaling|italic=true}} "No".
Some question words (sometimes called wh-words):
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" width="40%" |+ Some question words ! rowspan=2|Pronouns | {{lang|rma|niku|italic=true}} | "what" |- | {{lang|rma|taa|italic=true}} | "who" |- ! rowspan=2|Adverbs | {{lang|rma|ngarangki, ngarangsu|italic=true}} | "where" |- | {{lang|rma|niika bii|italic=true}} | "how" |}
Question words may be preceded by another sentence constituent as topic, e.g. {{lang|rma|Tiiskama '''taa''' yutaaku?|italic=true}} "Who took the child?" (child who took), {{lang|rma|Maa, '''ngarangki''' aakar?|italic=true}} "And you, where do you live?" (you, where live).
However, question words generally stand at the beginning of the sentence: {{lang|rma|'''Ngarangki''' maa aakar?|italic=true}} "Where do you live?" (where you live), {{lang|rma|'''Ngarangki''' ngulkang aakar?|italic=true}} "Where does the wari live?" (where wari lives), {{lang|rma|'''Ngarangki''' Nora aing nguu aakar?|italic=true}} "Where is Nora's house?" (where Nora GENITIVE house stay), {{lang|rma|'''Ngarangsu''' yaing taaki?|italic=true}} "Where is he/she going?" (where he/she goes), {{lang|rma|'''Ngarangsu''' yaing taata taaki?|italic=true}} "Where is his/her father going?" (where his/her father goes), {{lang|rma|'''Taa''' nsulaing rama kuup alkwsi?|italic=true}} "Who speaks our Rama language?" (who our Rama language speaks), {{lang|rma|'''Taa u''' mtaaku?|italic=true}} "With whom did you go?" (who with you-went).
Questions words with a non-verbal predicate: {{lang|rma|'''Niku''' maing aak?|italic=true}} "What is your name?", {{lang|rma|'''Niika bii''' maing kaulingdut?|italic=true}} "How is your family?"
==== Negation ==== Sentences may be negated by placing {{lang|rma|taama|italic=true}} after the verb or predicate, e.g. {{lang|rma|Nah ipang su aakar taama|italic=true}} "I do not live on Rama Cay", {{lang|rma|Maa rama kuup alkwsi taama|italic=true}} "You do not speak Rama", {{lang|rma|Naing nguu taara taama|italic=true}} "My house is not big", {{lang|rma|Naming tausung naing taama|italic=true}} "That dog is not mine", or by placing ''aa'' before the verb, e.g. {{lang|rma|Paalpa aa baanalpiu|italic=true}} "They didn't look for the manatee", {{lang|rma|Naas aa taak ikar|italic=true}} "I don't want to go".
There is a special negative word, {{lang|rma|angka|italic=true}}, to express impossibility, e.g. {{lang|rma|Nah angka aakar tawan ki|italic=true}} "I cannot live in Bluefields".
==== Coordination and subordination ==== Coordinating conjunctions: {{lang|rma|an|italic=true}} "and", {{lang|rma|barka|italic=true}} "but": {{lang|rma|Naing nising '''an''' naing tairung ning nguu ki aakar nah u|italic=true}} "My sister '''and''' my brother live in this house with me", {{lang|rma|Nah tausung saiming kuaakar '''an''' maa puus puksak kuaakar|italic=true}} "I have one dog '''and''' you have two cats", {{lang|rma|Naing nguu taara taama, '''barka''' aakwaala|italic=true}} "My house is not big, but it is pretty".
Subordinate clauses may be formed by means of subordinator suffixes as described above. Reported speech is formed by juxtaposition as in {{lang|rma|Anaapiu anaungi|italic=true}} "They found it, they say" ({{lang|rma|aapi|italic=true}} "find", {{lang|rma|aung|italic=true}} "say"). Relative clauses also have no specific subordinator but the clause marker {{lang|rma|kaing|italic=true}} may be employed, e.g. {{lang|rma|Suulikaas nipaayau kaing Neli aa nitangu|italic=true}} "The meat I bought, I gave it to Nelly" (meat I-bought {{lang|rma|kaing|italic=true}} Nelly OBJECT I-gave).
== Lexicon == Rama has borrowed words from Miskito (e.g. {{lang|rma|taara|italic=true}} "big"), English, Rama Cay Creole and Spanish.<ref>Words possibly borrowed from Miskito include some that Miskito ultimately borrowed from English, e.g. {{lang|rma|tawan|italic=true}} "town". There are probably also numerous Miskito calques in Rama, such as {{lang|rma|preya aing nguu|italic=true}} "church", cf. Miskito {{lang|rma|prias watla|italic=true}}.</ref> Besides such loans, Rama has a primary lexicon of Chibchan origin, expanded through various word-formation processes.
Many verb stems are made up of extensions from primary roots by the addition of one of the prefixes {{lang|rma|al-|italic=true}} and {{lang|rma|aa-|italic=true}}, which often correlate with intransitive and transitive meanings respectively. Evident intransitive derivation with {{lang|rma|al-|italic=true}} is illustrated by the pairs {{lang|rma|maling|italic=true}} "kill" : {{lang|rma|almaling|italic=true}} "die", {{lang|rma|aark : alaark|italic=true}} "break (tr./intr.)" and {{lang|rma|auk : alauk|italic=true}} "roast (tr./intr.)", while other cases of outward resemblance are semantically opaque, e.g. {{lang|rma|kwis|italic=true}} "eat" and {{lang|rma|alkwis|italic=true}} "speak", or involve more complex relationships, e.g. {{lang|rma|aap|italic=true}} (i.e. {{lang|rma|aa- + p|italic=true}}) "find" and {{lang|rma|baalp|italic=true}} ({{lang|rma|ba-|italic=true}} [preverb] + {{lang|rma|al + p|italic=true}} "seek".
Verbs may be derived from other parts of speech by suffixing one of several verbal roots glossed as "do, make", such as {{lang|rma|-king, -ting|italic=true}} and {{lang|rma|-uung|italic=true}}.
A common adjective-forming suffix is {{lang|rma|-ba|italic=true}}, while the participial suffix {{lang|rma|-ima|italic=true}} gives rise to both adjectives and nouns.
Certain recurrent endings found in numerous noun stems appear to correspond to vague semantic classes. A notable example is {{lang|rma|-up|italic=true}}, which occurs as the last component in nouns many of which denote round objects, fruits or body parts. As an [[inalienable noun]] in its own right, {{lang|rma|-up|italic=true}} means "eye" or "seed".
Composition is another common way of forming nouns, as in {{lang|rma|suulikaas|italic=true}} "meat" (from {{lang|rma|suuli|italic=true}} "animal" + {{lang|rma|kaas|italic=true}} "flesh") or the inalienable noun {{lang|rma|-upulis|italic=true}} "eyelash" (from {{lang|rma|-up|italic=true}} "eye" + {{lang|rma|ulis|italic=true}} "hair").
New concepts can also be expressed syntactically, e.g. through genitive constructions such as {{lang|rma|preya aing nguu|italic=true}} "church" (lit. house of prayer), or through verbal paraphrase.
Partial or complete reduplication is seen in the forms of some words, including onomatopoeics such as {{lang|rma|tahtah|italic=true}} "dripping", animal names like {{lang|rma|ngaukngauk|italic=true}} "spider" or {{lang|rma|tkwustkwus|italic=true}} "rabbit", colour names and other descriptive adjectives such as {{lang|rma|nuknuknga|italic=true}} "yellow", {{lang|rma|ngarngaringba|italic=true}} "green", {{lang|rma|siksiknga|italic=true}} "speckled", {{lang|rma|kingkingma|italic=true}} "calm", and others, e.g. {{lang|rma|tiskitiski|italic=true}} "a little".
Some recorded words that were claimed to be from the [[Corobicí language]] are actually from a dialect of Rama spoken in the region of [[Upala]].<ref>Adolfo Constenla, ''Comparative Chibchan Phonology'' (1981)</ref>
